Same spelling as the English word “moment,” used in phrases like “Un moment.”
Well-known first name—painter Vincent van Gogh, actor Vincent Cassel.

thoughts: English speakers already deal with a silent final “e,” but in French it behaves differently: it’s either completely dropped or reduced to a very quick neutral vowel /ə/. The trick is to avoid giving it the English long-“ee” or “ay” value.
description: When a plain, unaccented “e” sits at the very end of a French word, it is normally silent. Simply stop on the preceding consonant. In careful or poetic speech it can surface as a very short, relaxed “uh” (the neutral vowel you hear in the second syllable of English “sofa”), but never as “ee” or “ay.” Your lips and tongue stay relaxed; just release the consonant and you’re done.

example_words.cultural_context: Popular breakfast dish found on diner menus everywhere
Iconic French bread sold in supermarkets and sandwich shops
Famous sparkling wine used for celebrations

thoughts: Final -er in French is almost always the infinitive ending of the largest verb group.  English speakers often see it in phrases (je t’aime, bon appétit, savoir-faire) or in brand/ proper names like Parler.  The tricky part is remembering that the written r is silent and the vowel is a pure, closed “ay” sound, not the diphthong /eɪ/ and certainly not followed by an English r.
description: When -er comes at the very end of a French word it is pronounced as one clean, closed “ay” sound (IPA /e/).  Your tongue is mid-high and toward the front (like the vowel in English “say”) but you must stop there—do NOT let it glide into a y/ee off-glide and do NOT pronounce an r afterwards.  The written r is silent unless there is a liaison with the next word.

example_words.cultural_context: Name of a social-media platform frequently mentioned in U.S. news; spelled the same as the French verb
Seen on French menus or cooking shows; appears in phrases like “Bon appétit, mangez !”
Recognized from the famous phrase “Je t’aime” heard in films, songs, and pop culture

thoughts: “ez” is always at the very end of a French word and is pronounced exactly the same as the single letter “é”: a clean, closed e sound, similar to the vowel in English “say” but shorter and without a final y-glide. The written z is completely silent. English speakers have the vowel already, so the only new idea is remembering not to pronounce the z.
description: Say a short, pure "ay" sound (IPA /e/). Keep your tongue forward and your lips only slightly spread, and do NOT pronounce any final z sound. Think of ending English “say” halfway through, before the tongue glides up.

example_words.cultural_context: Seen in restaurant names like “Chez Panisse” or phrases such as “chez moi” (at my place).
Heard in sports chants like “Allez les Bleus!” during French soccer or cycling events.
Part of the well-known tourist phrase “Parlez-vous français?”

thoughts: Final –es in French is usually pronounced /e/ (like the “ay” in English “day,” but shorter and without the y-glide) while the written s itself is silent unless liaison occurs. English speakers have seen it in names such as “Les Misérables,” yet they often keep the English z-sound or pronounce the s. Mouth in mid-close, lips slightly spread, quick clean vowel, then stop—no consonant sound.
description: When –es comes at the very end of a standalone French word of one syllable (les, des, mes etc.), say a single, pure “ay” sound /e/. Do NOT voice the written s; it is silent unless the next word begins with a vowel, in which case it links as /z/. Compared with English “day,” make it shorter and crisper and avoid the final y-glide.

example_words.cultural_context: Blockbuster musical and film based on Victor Hugo’s novel

Classic electric-guitar model and the name of its famous inventor

thoughts: Final “x” in French is almost always silent, so the main hurdle for English speakers is resisting the urge to pronounce an /ks/ or /z/. They may have encountered this in imported words like “faux” or names like “Grand Prix,” but might not consciously realize the x is mute.
description: When an “x” appears at the very end of a standalone French word, it is normally NOT pronounced at all; you simply finish on the preceding vowel or consonant sound. For example, “prix” sounds like “pree,” and “faux” sounds like “foh.” (A few rare exceptions—mostly numbers like six/dix—use an /s/ or change in liaison, but the general rule is silent.)

example_words.cultural_context: Known from Formula 1 races called the Grand Prix
Used in English fashion and décor to mean “fake,” as in faux fur
Famous French wine region and wine label frequently seen in restaurants and stores

thoughts: English speakers tend to assume any written “s” is pronounced /s/. In French, a final “s” is usually silent, which can surprise learners. They must learn to ignore the written letter and end the word on the preceding vowel or consonant sound.
description: When an “s” is the last letter in a French word, it is normally NOT pronounced. Simply stop the word before the “s,” letting the previous vowel or consonant be the last audible sound. (The written “s” usually marks plurals or certain grammar endings, but it stays silent in speech unless a liaison is required.)

example_words.cultural_context: World-famous capital city, often mentioned in travel, movies, and fashion

thoughts: Final ‑t in French is normally silent. English already has several loan-words that keep this French spelling, so learners have seen the pattern, but they still tend to pronounce the final /t/. Main task is to remember to drop the consonant completely unless there is a liaison.
description: When a single letter “t” appears at the very end of a standalone French word, you simply do NOT pronounce it. Your tongue stays relaxed—there is no brief closure or release like the English /t/. The word ends on the vowel or nasal sound that comes just before the written “t.”

example_words.cultural_context: Famous dance style; same spelling used in English

thoughts: English speakers already know the letter D, but they are used to pronouncing it at the end of words. In French, a written final “d” is usually silent, so the challenge is remembering *not* to voice it.
description: When the letter “d” is the very last letter in a French word, it is normally silent: you simply stop the sound on the preceding vowel or nasal vowel and do not add a voiced-d release. (Example: “grand” is pronounced roughly like “grahn,” without a final /d/.) In a few short compass-point words such as “sud” or in liaison before a following vowel, the /d/ can be heard, but as a rule of thumb, assume silence.

thoughts: English speakers already know the sound /p/, but here the key point is that a written final “p” in French is normally NOT pronounced at all. Remembering to keep it completely silent—no puff of air—is the challenge.
description: When the letter “p” appears at the very end of a French word, you do not pronounce it. Your lips may close briefly as they move to the next word, but you release no burst of air and produce no audible consonant. In careful speech you often end the word on the preceding vowel or nasal sound and simply stop.

thoughts: English speakers already know the voiced “hard g” /g/ as in “go.” In French, when a single g is written at the very end of a word (not “ng”), it is almost always the same sound: a voiced velar stop. It is released a bit more softly than some English speakers do, but otherwise identical. Because the sound already exists in English, recognition and production are straightforward.
description: A voiced velar stop, made by touching the back of the tongue to the soft palate and releasing it while the vocal cords vibrate – exactly like the hard g in English “tag.” In French, you do not add a following schwa; end the word crisply on the consonant.

example_words.cultural_context: Used in French for graffiti or social-media hashtag; same spelling as English "tag"
The loan-word for an online journal; identical to English "blog"
Describes a back-and-forth line; same word in English

thoughts: Final –ps is usually silent in modern French: neither the P nor the S is released, so the word ends on the preceding vowel (often a nasal vowel). English speakers may want to pronounce /ps/ like in “lapse,” but they must resist that impulse.
description: When a French word ends in the letters “ps,” you normally do NOT pronounce either consonant. Simply finish on the previous vowel sound (which may be nasal, as in temps /tɑ̃/). Your lips stay relaxed; no closing for a /p/ and no hissing /s/. Think of it as the letters just being written, not spoken.

thoughts: Final “c” in French is almost always the same hard /k/ sound English speakers make at the ends of words like “back.” It’s therefore very familiar and rarely causes trouble.
description: Make the unvoiced hard “k” sound: raise the back of the tongue to the soft palate to block the air, then release it quickly. In French the release is softer than in English—little to no burst of air (aspiration)—but otherwise it feels like saying the last sound in English “lock.”

thoughts: “eaux” is simply the plural form of “eau.”  The written chunk looks exotic, but it is pronounced exactly the same as the single-letter English interjection “oh.”  The tricky part is remembering that the final “x” is always silent.
description: Pronounce it as a single, pure “oh” sound, like the English word “go” without the final –guh.  Your lips round a bit and stay steady; nothing else is voiced.  The written “x” never makes a sound.

Seen on dessert menus and baking shows as the plural of “gâteau” (fancy cakes)

thoughts: The French ending “aux” is silent except for a single, pure /o/ vowel. Many English speakers have met it in words like “faux fur.” Because the spelling looks very different from the sound, the main hurdle is remembering that the final x is never pronounced.
description: When “aux” appears at the end of a French word, the three letters together are pronounced as one long closed “oh” sound, like the vowel in English “go,” but shorter and without the off-glide you might make in English. The final x is completely silent.
